awd_titl_txt: Decisions from Experience and the Role of Feedback in Environmental Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite frequent and vivid reminders of the destruction that natural disasters can leave in their wake, compliance rates with evacuation orders and support for mitigation efforts remain troublingly low. One possible contributing factor to this apparent under-weighting of the risk from environmental hazards is the fact that when making decisions between uncertain outcomes in laboratory studies, people appear to treat rare events differently if their probabilities are learned through sampling and feedback (experience), as opposed to summary statistics (descriptions). Despite a recent surge in laboratory research on this topic, it is not yet clear how, or whether, this effect applies in the far more complex environment of real-world decisions about hazard preparedness. The current research project systematically investigates how learning about environmental hazards through personal experience affects people's perceptions of (and therefore their actions in response to) such dangers. The results provide a framework for scientists and policymakers to better understand how the public's personal experience with those natural hazards might interact with -- or override -- the descriptive warning information they disseminate. Appreciation of the psychological hurdles to the understanding or use of such information can improve the influence of hazard forecasts, increasing compliance with warnings and protective measures. 

The Description-Experience (DE) Gap in risky choice describes the shift from Prospect Theory's predicted over-weighting of rare events when probabilities are learned through summary statistics (description), to an apparent under-weighting of small probabilities when learning occurs through repeated feedback (experience). This research program develops methods to extend existing findings about the DE gap into laboratory paradigms that more closely address the complexities inherent to real-world environmental decisions such as how to prepare for potential hazards. The research then validates existing findings through field studies that examine decisions from real-world experiences and assess the validity of prior results. Field studies integrate choice problems used in the laboratory studies into realistic paradigms, and test the boundaries of the type, timing, and valence of feedback typically used in DE gap studies. By converging evidence from well-controlled laboratory tasks and the richer, more complex set of real-world choices that people face every day, this program of research addresses current theory more thoroughly and effectively than either approach could alone. Insight into how provision of probability and outcome information in different ways affects real-world decisions illuminates ways of communicating information about environmental hazards to increase the likelihood that people will take protective action.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored how information that is experienced first-hand informs future decisions, termed “decisions from experience.” When we make decisions about rare, risky events, we tend to give less weight to probabilities that we experience than their likelihood would suggest, while for probabilities that are described to us we tend to give them more weight than might be warranted. When we make choices between multiple alternatives, our past experience can also inform our choice in numerous ways. Yet many economic models underweight the importance of this experience on our decisions. The goal of this project was to expand our understanding of how people’s experience influences their decision processes and their choices and to explore interventions that improve decision making.

In risky contexts, we found that existing theories about decisions from experience do not adequately explain people's choice behavior in situations that differ even slightly from the original studies that developed the theory (in other words, our results suggest that the underweighting theory lacks robust external validity). These conclusions could lead to development of more valid theory to explain the phenomena seen in decisions about rare events.

This research also explored the processes by which experience influences decisions. First we found influences of the order in which choices are presented on the way these choices are encoded and recalled and on future decision making. Specifically, we found that the value of choice options that are experienced earlier in a sequence are more accurately encoded in memory. This leads to a bias towards this first choice option when facing a decision between two, objectively equally valued, options - if the first option is desirable. If the first option was not desirable or low in value, the alternative will be preferred, even in the case of both options having objectively equal values. This influence of choice order on preference formation can inform decision design.

Finally, this research explored how to intervene when past experiences can influence our decision-making process in harmful ways. First, we found evidence that setting an appropriate default can help those with strong habits adjust to a context when their habitual decision is not the best option, and that this happens by changing the way people search for information. Second, we also found that encouraging people to reflect on positive past experiences with the values they hold influences future decision making. We find that this positive interaction with personal values leads people to feel more connected to the self which in turn promotes more pro-social decisions. Third, we found that our experience with environmental behaviors influences our future environmental decisions for large investments as well as small behaviors. We also found preliminary evidence that the way in which these large investment decisions are framed may influence the qualitative role of past experience in choice.

This work has several broader impacts for how we understand and might intervene in decision-making processes. First, we provide potential boundary conditions to update current formulas about how we reason from past events. Second, we have identified interventions that draw on past experience to better align prosocial decision-making with preferences. Increasing our connection to our past experiences (through values affirmation or with environmental messages) can increase preference-aligned prosocial and proenvironmental behaviors. These findings can be applied to lead to meaningful improvements in social and environmental domains, either as a complement to or in the absence of supporting policies. This work has been disseminated to other researchers and decision architects in the energy and environmental domains through presentation at a variety of venues including the Society for Judgment and Decision Making Conference and the Behavior, Energy, and Climate Change Conference. This work is also being written up for publication in peer-reviewed journals.
